text.p: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto condemned some Japanese citizens on Wednesday for harassing Peruvian residents following the seizure of the Japanese ambassador's home in Lima by Marxist rebels.
"It's a shame. No one must harass (Peruvian residents) when we are fighting terrorists," Hashimoto told reporters.
Shops and cars owned by Peruvians in Isezaki, some 100 km (65 miles) north of Tokyo, have been stoned in an outbreak of Peru-bashing by Japanese residents there.
The Peruvian-Japanese community in Isezaki and the surrounding area is perhaps the largest in Japan, accounting for about 4,000 of the 15,000 Peruvians in the country.

"I fear this is setting off a kind of mood of bullying or discrimination against us by the Japanese," Kiyoshi Machida, a Bolivian of Japanese descent who runs a restaurant mostly for Peruvian-Japanese, said on Tuesday.
Machida's restaurant "La Bodeguita" serves as a community centre for the immigrant workers in Isezaki.

Last Friday, three days after Marxist guerrillas stormed into the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima and took hundreds of hostages, someone threw a rock through the windshield of Machida's small van parked behind his restaurant.
On the same day, a fist-size block of concrete was thrown into a grocery store run by Peruvian-Japanese Pedro Nishimata.
No one has been injured in the incidents in the town.
